Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 /* TraceToEarth, Copyright (c) 1999 Michael G. Henderson <mghenderson@lanl.gov>
00002  *
00003  *    - Attempts to trace FL down to (some height above) the Earth.
00004  *     
00005  *
00006  *
00007  * Permission to use, copy, modify, distribute, and sell this software and its
00008  * documentation for any purpose is hereby granted without fee, provided that
00009  * the above copyright notice appear in all copies and that both that
00010  * copyright notice and this permission notice appear in supporting
00011  * documentation.  No representations are made about the suitability of this
00012  * software for any purpose.  It is provided "as is" without express or
00013  * implied warranty.
00014  *
00015  */
00016 
00017 #include <stdio.h>
00018 #include <stdlib.h>
00019 #include "Lgm/Lgm_MagModelInfo.h"
00020 #include "Lgm/Lgm_WGS84.h"
00021 
00022 
00023 
00024 
00025 int Lgm_TraceToEarth( Lgm_Vector *u, Lgm_Vector *v, double TargetHeight, double sgn, double tol, Lgm_MagModelInfo *Info ) {
00026 
00027     Lgm_Vector  u_scale;
00028     double      Htry, Htry_max, Hdid, Hnext, Hmin, Hmax, s;
00029     double      Sa=0.0, Sc=0.0, d;
00030     double      Rinitial, Fa, Fb, Fc, F;
00031     double      Height, StartHeight;
00032     double      Height_a, Height_b, Height_c, HeightPlus, HeightMinus, direction;
00033     Lgm_Vector  Pa, Pc, P;
00034     int         done, reset, AboveTargetHeight;
00035 
00036 
00037     /*
00038      * Determine our initial geocentric radius in km. (u is assumed to be in
00039      * units of Re where we define Re to be WGS84_A.)
00040      */
00041     Rinitial = WGS84_A*Lgm_Magnitude( u ); // km
00042 //printf( "Lgm_TraceToEarth: Rinitial = %g km\n", Rinitial);
00043 
00044 
00045     /*
00046      * The Earth is a spheroid. It is more flattened at the poles than at the
00047      * equator.  Check to see if we are initially at a height where we need to
00048      * worry about it. For WGS84 Earth shape model, the equatorial radius is
00049      * WGS84_A and polar radius is WGS84_B (WGS84_B is about 20km smaller than
00050      * WGS84_A).
00051      */
00052     if ( Rinitial < WGS84_B ) {
00053 
00054         // must be inside the Earth, which is no good -- bail with
00055         // LGM_INSIDE_EARTH error code
00056         return( LGM_INSIDE_EARTH );
00057 
00058     } else {
00059 
00060         // We are at least at or above WGS84_B. We could still be in trouble in
00061         // terms of being inside the Earth, so we have to check more
00062         // thouroughly now.  Determine Geodetic Height
00063         Lgm_WGS84_to_GeodHeight( u, &Height );
00064 Height = WGS84_A*(Lgm_Magnitude( u )-1.0);
00065 
00066         if ( Height < 0.0 )  {
00067 
00068             // inside the Earth, which is no good -- bail with error
00069             return( LGM_INSIDE_EARTH );
00070 
00071         }
00072 
00073     }
00074 
00075 
00076     /*
00077      *  If we get here, the initial point must be above the surface of the
00078      *  (spheroidal) Earth.
00079      *
00080      *  Now check to see if we are currently above or below the target height.
00081      */
00082     AboveTargetHeight = ( Height > TargetHeight ) ? TRUE : FALSE;
00083 //printf( "Lgm_TraceToEarth: Height, TargetHeight = %g, %g km\n", Height, TargetHeight);
00084 //printf( "Lgm_TraceToEarth: AboveTargetHeight = %d\n", AboveTargetHeight );
00085 
00086 
00087 
00088     /*
00089      * Initialize some things
00090      */
00091     Pa.x = Pa.y = Pa.z = 0.0;
00092     Pc.x = Pc.y = Pc.z = 0.0;
00093     P = *u;
00094     Hmax = Info->Hmax;
00095     Hmin = 0.001;
00096     u_scale.x =  100.0;  u_scale.y = 100.0; u_scale.z = 100.0;
00097     Height = Height_a = Height_b = Height_c = 0.0;
00098     F = Fa = Fb = Fc = 0.0;
00099 
00100 
00101 
00102     /*
00103      * Save initial point if we need to 
00104      */
00105     if (Info->SavePoints) fprintf(Info->fp, "%f \t%f\t %f\t 3\n", u->x, u->y, u->z);
00106 
00107 
00108 
00109     /*
00110      * If we are above the target height, a potential problem will occur if the
00111      * field line is open in the direction of tracing.  Fortunately, that
00112      * situation is easy to detect and is taken care of later...
00113      *
00114      * Here we need to test for and deal with the opposite problem. If we are
00115      * already below the target height, it is possible that the field line
00116      * never gets high enough to reach the target height. This is more tricky
00117      * to deal with because we can run the risk of getting below the surface of
00118      * the Earth.  We need to try to get back above the target height to test
00119      * for this.  If we cannot get above we need to bail out of the routine
00120      * altogether.
00121      */
00122     StartHeight = Height;
00123     if ( !AboveTargetHeight ){
00124 
00125 
00126         /*
00127          *  Determine which direction along the field line will take us higher.
00128          */
00129         Htry = 0.01;
00130 
00131         // sgn = +1
00132         P = *u; Lgm_MagStep( &P, &u_scale, Htry, &Hdid, &Hnext, 1.0e-7, 1.0, &s, &reset, Info->Bfield, Info );
00133         Lgm_WGS84_to_GeodHeight( &P, &HeightPlus );
00134 HeightPlus = WGS84_A*(Lgm_Magnitude( &P )-1.0);
00135 
00136         // sgn = -1
00137         P = *u; Lgm_MagStep( &P, &u_scale, Htry, &Hdid, &Hnext, 1.0e-7, -1.0, &s, &reset, Info->Bfield, Info );
00138         Lgm_WGS84_to_GeodHeight( &P, &HeightMinus );
00139 HeightMinus = WGS84_A*(Lgm_Magnitude( &P )-1.0);
00140 
00141         direction = ( HeightPlus > HeightMinus ) ? 1.0 : -1.0;
00142 
00143 
00144 
00145         /* 
00146          *  We are already at or below target height. Trace until we are not.
00147          */
00148         done  = FALSE;
00149         reset = TRUE;
00150         while ( !done ) {
00151             Htry = fabs(0.9*(TargetHeight - Height));       // This computes Htry as 90% of the distance to the TargetHeight
00152             if (Htry > 0.1) Htry = 0.1; // If its bigger than 0.1 reset it to 0.1 -- to be safe.
00153             Lgm_MagStep( &P, &u_scale, Htry, &Hdid, &Hnext, 1.0e-7, direction, &s, &reset, Info->Bfield, Info );
00154             Lgm_WGS84_to_GeodHeight( &P, &Height );
00155 Height = WGS84_A*(Lgm_Magnitude( &P )-1.0);
00156             F = Height - TargetHeight;
00157             if ( F > 0.0 ){
00158                 done = TRUE;
00159             } else if ( Height < StartHeight ) {
00160                 // We are going back down again -- Target Height unreachable? -- Bail out
00161                 return( LGM_TARGET_HEIGHT_UNREACHABLE );
00162             }
00163         }
00164 
00165     }
00166   
00167 
00168 
00169 
00170 
00171 
00172 
00173 
00174     /*
00175      *  Bracket the zero first. 
00176      *  We want to stop in the ionosphere at a certain height above the Earth.
00177      *  We need to find 2 points along the field line such that the
00178      *  intersection of the FL with the spheroid is guaranteed to lie between
00179      *  them. To do this, we need to find two points; Pa and Pc such that;
00180      *  
00181      *      and  Height( Pa ) - TargetHeight   >   0.0
00182      *      and  Height( Pc ) - TargetHeight   <   0.0
00183      *
00184      *  I.e., F = Height - TargetHeight has opposite signs
00185      * 
00186      *  Set the start point, Pa and Fa. (Fa is difference between Height_a and
00187      *  TargetHeight.)
00188      *
00189      */
00190     Pa   = P;
00191     Lgm_WGS84_to_GeodHeight( &Pa, &Height_a );
00192 Height_a = WGS84_A*(Lgm_Magnitude( &Pa )-1.0);
00193     Sa   = 0.0;
00194 
00195 //printf( "Lgm_TraceToEarth: Pa = <%g, %g, %g> Re\n", Pa.x, Pa.y, Pa.z );
00196 //printf( "Lgm_TraceToEarth: Height_a = %g\n", Height_a );
00197 
00198     /*
00199      *  Get an initial Htry that is safe -- i.e. start off slowly
00200      *  We dont really know where we are, so be conservative on the first try.
00201      *  If Lgm_MagStep() gives back an Hnext thats higher, we'll crank Htry up then...
00202      */
00203     Htry = 0.9*Height_a;        // This computes Htry as 90% of the distance to the Earth's surface (could be small if we are already close!)
00204     if (Htry > 0.1) Htry = 0.1; // If its bigger than 0.1 reset it to 0.1 -- to be safe.
00205     
00206 
00207 
00208     /*
00209      *  Keep stepping along the field line until we drop below the target
00210      *  height, TargetHeight.  (Or bail if its open). This completes the endpoints of the
00211      *  bracket pair. We get these points first, because there are field lines
00212      *  that have more than one local minimum in fabs(Height-TargetHeight). So find Pa and Pc
00213      *  first and then complete the triple later. CHECK on this. I changed this
00214      *  from a minima search to a simple root finder. Is it OK still?
00215      */
00216     P     = Pa;
00217     done  = FALSE;
00218     reset = TRUE;
00219     while ( !done ) {
00220 
00221         Lgm_MagStep( &P, &u_scale, Htry, &Hdid, &Hnext, 1.0e-7, sgn, &s, &reset, Info->Bfield, Info );
00222         Lgm_WGS84_to_GeodHeight( &P, &Height );
00223 Height = WGS84_A*(Lgm_Magnitude( &P )-1.0);
00224         F =  Height - TargetHeight;
00225         if ((F > 0.0) && (Info->SavePoints)) fprintf(Info->fp, "%f \t%f\t %f\t 2\n", P.x, P.y, P.z);
00226 
00227             if (   (P.x > Info->OpenLimit_xMax) || (P.x < Info->OpenLimit_xMin) || (P.y > Info->OpenLimit_yMax) || (P.y < Info->OpenLimit_yMin)
00228                 || (P.z > Info->OpenLimit_zMax) || (P.z < Info->OpenLimit_zMin) ) {
00229             /*
00230              *  Open FL!
00231              */
00232             v->x = v->y = v->z = 0.0;
00233             return(0);
00234         } else if ( F < 0.0 ) {
00235             done = TRUE;
00236             Pc = P;
00237             Height_c = Height;
00238             Fc = F;
00239             Sc += Hdid;
00240         } else {
00241             Pa = P;
00242             Fa = F;
00243             Height_a = Height;
00244             Sa = 0.0;
00245         }
00246 
00247         Htry = Hnext; // adaptively reset Htry
00248 
00249         /*
00250          *  Go no farther than some small distance below 
00251          *  the target Height. Also respect Hmin and Hmax.
00252          */
00253         Htry_max = 0.9*Height;
00254         if (Htry > Htry_max)  Htry = Htry_max;
00255         if      (Htry < Hmin) Htry = Hmin;
00256         else if (Htry > Hmax) Htry = Hmax;
00257 
00258 
00259     }
00260 
00261 
00262 
00263 
00264     /*
00265      *  We have a bracket. Now go in for the kill.
00266      *
00267      *  (Note: If all we wanted to know is whether or not the line hits the
00268      *  TargetHeight, we could stop here: it must or we wouldnt have a minimum
00269      *  bracketed.)
00270      *
00271      *  Use golden-section search to converge toward minimum.
00272      *  (Sa, Sb, Sc) are the distances of the triple points along
00273      *  the FL. For convenience, we maintain Sa = 0.0, so that
00274      *  Sb and Sc are always the distances relative to Pa. (And
00275      *  so Sc is always the width of the bracketed interval. So when
00276      *  Sc gets small enough we bail out and take Pb as the min).
00277      *
00278      */
00279     done  = FALSE;
00280     reset = TRUE;
00281 //printf( "Lgm_TraceToEarth: About to go in for kill \n");
00282     while (!done) {
00283 
00284         d = Sc - Sa;
00285     
00286         if ( fabs(F) < tol ) {
00287             done = TRUE;
00288         } else {
00289 
00290             P = Pa; Htry = 0.5*d;
00291             Lgm_MagStep( &P, &u_scale, Htry, &Hdid, &Hnext, 1.0e-7, sgn, &s, &reset, Info->Bfield, Info );
00292             Lgm_WGS84_to_GeodHeight( &P, &Height );
00293 Height = WGS84_A*(Lgm_Magnitude( &P )-1.0);
00294             F =  Height - TargetHeight;
00295 //printf( "Lgm_TraceToEarth: Inside kill loop. Htry, F = %g %g %g\n", Htry, tol, F);
00296             if ( F >= 0.0 ) {
00297                 Pa = P; Fa = F; Sa += Hdid;
00298             } else {
00299                 Pc = P; Fc = F; Sc = Sa + Hdid;
00300             }
00301 
00302         }
00303     }
00304 
00305 
00306 
00307     /*
00308      *  Take average as the final answer.
00309      */
00310     v->x = 0.5*(Pa.x + Pc.x); v->y = 0.5*(Pa.y + Pc.y); v->z = 0.5*(Pa.z + Pc.z);
00311     if (Info->SavePoints) fprintf(Info->fp, "%f \t%f\t %f\t 2\n", v->x, v->y, v->z);
00312 
00313     return( 1 );
00314 
00315 }
00316 
00317 /*
00318  *   $id$
00319  */
